title: 107_s1541
content:
The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" can be cited as the short title. Federal-State agreements are addressed in the act. The "Temporary Emergency Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001" allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor to provide temporary emergency unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted all regular compensation rights and are not receiving compensation from any other source. Under the unemployment compensation law of Canada, individuals can exhaust their rights to regular compensation when they have received all available payments based on employment or wages during their base period, or when their rights have been terminated due to the expiration of the benefit year. The weekly benefit amount for temporary emergency unemployment compensation is equal to the regular compensation payable under the State law for a week of total unemployment. The State law applies to claims for temporary emergency unemployment compensation, with the maximum amount payable not exceeding the established account balance. Governors can trigger an extended compensation period for individuals who have exhausted regular compensation rights under State law. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. The State will establish temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount in the account equal to 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount. The account may be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. The State establishes temporary emergency unemployment compensation accounts for eligible individuals, with the amount equal to 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount. The account may be reduced by any extended compensation received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. Allowances under State law payable to the individual for total unemployment are included in the account. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH AGREEMENTS FOR TEMPORARY EMERGENCY UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION. Payments to states with agreements for temporary emergency unemployment compensation shall be equal to 100 percent of the compensation paid to individuals. States will not receive payment if entitled to reimbursement under other federal laws. The amount payable to each state will be determined by the Secretary in advance or as reimbursement. The Secretary can adjust payments to states based on prior estimates, using agreed-upon methods for accuracy. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. Funds from the extended unemployment compensation account in the Unemployment Trust Fund are used to make payments to States with agreements under this title. The Secretary certifies payments to States, and the Secretary of the Treasury makes payments to States accordingly. Appropriations are made to assist States in meeting administration costs under this title. Authorization of appropriations from the Treasury's general fund to the extended unemployment compensation account of the Unemployment Trust Fund is provided without fiscal year limitation. The Secretary estimates necessary sums for payments under this section for specific types of compensation, which do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. Individuals who knowingly make false statements or fail to disclose material facts to receive unauthorized temporary emergency unemployment compensation will be ineligible for further benefits and may face prosecution. They will also be required to repay the amount received. The State agency may waive repayment of emergency unemployment compensation if it was without fault on the individual's part and repayment would be against equity. The agency can recover the amount by deducting from future unemployment benefits within 3 years of receiving the unauthorized payment. The State agency may waive repayment of emergency unemployment compensation if it was without fault on the individual's part and repayment would be against equity. No deduction exceeding 50 percent of the weekly benefit amount can be made without a fair hearing and final determination. Any determination by the State agency under this section is subject to review in the same manner as determinations under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. Terms such as "compensation", "benefit year", and "week" are defined under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970.

SEC. 8. APPLICABILITY. Agreements under this Act apply to weeks of unemployment starting after the agreement and ending within 18 months of the Act's enactment.

SEC. 9. TEMPORARY REDUCTION IN INTEREST RATE FOR STATE UNEMPLOYMENT FUND ADVANCES. The rate of interest paid by a State on advances made under the Social Security Act will be reduced from 10 percent to 5 percent for a period of 18 months after the enactment of the Act.
